chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with a suspected insect bite or sting?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Take a history from the person asking about:

  • Onset, site and duration of symptoms including:
    • Local symptoms such as pain, swelling and erythema and,
    • Symptoms that may indicate a systemic reaction such as urticaria, rhinitis, wheezing, abdominal pain, vomiting, and dizziness.
  • Risk factors for insect bites or stings such as occupation, contact with domestic pets, camping, gardening, or walking in wooded/heath areas.
  • Witnessed exposure to a bite or sting from a specific insect. Consider potential pathogens transmitted by specific insects such as:
    • Lyme disease associated with tick bites — for more information, see the CKS topic on Lyme disease.
    • Malaria associated with mosquito bites — for more information, see the CKS topic on Malaria.
  • History of serious reactions to insect bites or stings.
  • Use of over-the-counter and prescribed preparations — in some people, topical preparations can cause allergic or sensitivity reactions.  

Examine the person looking for:

  • Signs of systemic hypersensitivity reaction (SR) — SRs usually develop rapidly within minutes of a sting. For more information, see the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis.
    • Symptoms and signs of a mild SR include pruritus, urticarial, erythema, mild angioedema, rhinitis, and conjunctivitis.
    • Symptoms and signs of a moderate SR include mild asthma, moderate angio-oedema, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, and mild, transient light headedness or dizziness.
    • Symptoms and signs of a severe (potentially life-threatening) SR include swelling of the mucous membranes, airway compromise (such as bronchospasm or laryngeal oedema), hypotension, tachycardia, collapse or loss of consciousness.
    • Occasionally a late-onset reaction such as an urticarial rash or serum sickness-like reaction with urticaria, joint swelling and arthralgia can develop several hours after a sting.
  • Signs of a systemic toxic reaction following multiple stings such as:
    • Hypotension, severe headache, diarrhoea, vomiting and shock.
  • Signs of an insect bite or sting:
    • Bee sting — the sting may still be visible in the skin (remove immediately).
    • Flea bites — bites from cat or dog fleas are typically found below the knees.
    • Bed bugs — pruritic maculopapular lesions with haemorrhagic punctums (the site of the bite) may appear on exposed skin about 10 days after a bite from a bed bug.
      • Other presentations include isolated pruritis, nodules, bullae or urticaria.
      • Large numbers of bites can lead to widespread erythema or urticaria.
      • Suspect bed bugs if similar symptoms develop in people sharing a bed or travelling together.
    • Tick bites — the tick itself may be visible in the skin (remove immediately unless known to be allergic to ticks).
      • Acute tick bites may appear as an erythematous macule, papule or nodule.
      • Bites from infected ticks may result in Lyme disease which can present with erythema migrans (sometimes called a bullseye rash). For more information, see the CKS topic on Lyme disease.
    • Horse flies and stable flies — painful bites which may bleed and often become secondarily infected.
    • Midge bites — typically multiple small papular lesions on exposed skin.
    • Spider bites — may leave 2 clearly visible puncture wounds.
    • Head, body and pubic lice — can lead to excoriation due to itching caused by louse salivary antigens. For more information see the CKS topics on Head lice and Pubic lice.

Investigations

  • Investigations are not usually required as generally the diagnosis of an insect bite or sting can be made from the history and examination.
    • Investigations for severe reactions to insect bites or stings should be carried out in secondary care.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of a person with a suspected insect bite or sting are based on the clinical guidelines Stinging insect hypersensitivity: A practice parameter update 2011 [Golden et al, 2011] and Diagnosis and management of hymenoptera venom allergy: British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) guidelines [Krishna et al, 2011], expert opinion in a clinical textbook [Monsel et al, 2016] and review articles [Doggett and Russell, 2009; DTB, 2012].

  • Attempts to identify the type of insect causing bites or stings is important as de-infestation measures may be needed for example for bites caused by bedbugs or fleas [DTB, 2012].
